Abdul Kader Kabbani (Stanford University) Theodoros Salonidis (Thomson)
Key features Multi-hop wireless networks Tree logical structures
Applications WiFi mesh networks (802.11s) Mobile Multihop Relay (MMR) 802.16j
Primary interference Constraints due to single-radio limitation Links with common node endpoints
Links with distinct node endpoints Endpoints should not be within range
Two kinds of systems Multi-channel: only primary interference Single-channel: both primary and
Primary interference Constraints due to single-radio limitation Links with common node endpoints

Operation Slot-Synchronization Fixed-size multi-slot frames Frame = Scheduling Phase + Data phase
S D S D S D
Frame i-1 Frame i Frame i+1
Data phase: a set of conflict-free links must transmit Scheduling phase: decides the link set of data phase
Scheduling policy at Data phase Which conflict-free links should be scheduled to
Scheduling phase How can the nodes decide the conflict-free set using a
Scheduling policy in Data Phase MWIS policy: Select a set of conflict
free links with maximum sum of queue backlogs [Tassiulas92]
No efficient centralized or distributed protocol exists to date
No bound on scheduling phase duration
Scheduling policy in Data Phase MWIS policy: Select a set of conflict
free links with maximum sum of queue backlogs [Tassiulas92]
Scheduling policy in Data Phase Select a maximal conflict-free link set
Performance guarantees Single-channel: >1/8 of feasible rates Multi-channel: >1/2 of feasible rates
Scheduling policy in Data Phase Select a maximal conflict-free link set
Performance guarantees Single-channel: > 1/8 of feasible rates Multi-channel: > 1/2 of feasible rates
For any WBN network Maximum throughput scheduling can be realized in at most
WBN-MWIS distributed protocol For both single-channel and multi-channel systems
Conflict Graph (CG) Edge xy = link x and link y interfere
WBN CG recursive property At least one vertex v forms a clique with all its neighbors. When v is removed, resulting subgraph has same property
Conflict Graph (CG) Edge xy = link x and link y interfere

Minimize number of slots in scheduling phase Exploit spatial reuse for both Weight-phase and MWIS
phase. For regular tree topologies O(logN) (constant per frame).
Per-frame overhead typically less than 10% Lower overhead for multi-channel systems
Relative throughput performance Maximal provides 1/8 rates of WBN-MWIS
Overhead ratio r=BWN-MWIS/Maximal for D-ary trees of depth L (single-channel systems) 0.02% < r < 75% E.g. D=2, L=5, WBN-MWIS
has 50% overhead of Maximal Exponential decrease on L Polynomial decrease on D
WBN-MWIS: a distributed maximum throughput scheduling protocol of low complexity. Offline: enumeration procedure Online: weight phase + MWIS phase Overhead
Does not depend on weights O(N) in worst case and O(logN) after offline optimizations. Low in practice, both in absolute terms and relative to
